abstract.text: A Core Animation layer that Metal can render into, typically displayed onscreen.

inlineContent.text: Use a
when you want to use Metal to render a layer’s contents; for example, to render into a view. Consider using
instead, because this class automatically wraps a
object and provides a higher-level abstraction.
If you’re using UIKit, to create a view that uses a
, create a subclass of
and override its
class method to return a
If you’re using AppKit, configure an
object to use a backing layer and assign a
object to the view:
Adjust the layer’s properties to configure its underlying pixel format and other display behaviors.
A
creates a pool of Metal drawable objects (

). At any given time, one of these drawable objects contains the contents of the layer. To change the layer’s contents, ask the layer for a drawable object, render into it, and then update the layer’s contents to point to the new drawable.
Call the layer’s
method to obtain a drawable object. Get the drawable object’s texture and create a render pass that renders to that texture, as shown in the code below:
To change the layer’s contents to the new drawable, call the
method (or one of its variants) on the command buffer containing the encoded render pass, passing in the drawable object to present.
The layer reuses a drawable only if it isn’t onscreen and there are no strong references to it. Further, if a drawable isn’t available when you call

, the system waits for one to become available. To avoid stalls in your app, request a new drawable only when you need it, and release any references to it as quickly as possible after you’re done with it.

For example, before retrieving a new drawable, you might perform other work on the CPU or submit commands to the GPU that don’t require the drawable. Then, obtain the drawable and encode a command buffer to render into it, as described above. After you commit this command buffer, release all strong references to the drawable. If you don’t release drawables correctly, the layer runs out of drawables, and future calls to
return
Don’t release the drawable explicitly; instead, embed your render loop within an autorelease pool block:
This block releases drawables promptly and avoids possible deadlock situations with multiple drawables. Release drawables as soon as possible after committing your onscreen render pass.
As of iOS 10 and tvOS 10, you can safely retain a drawable to query its properties, such as
and
, after the system has presented it. If you don’t need to query these properties, release the drawable when you no longer need it.

abstract.text: The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
Presents a drawable as early as possible.
A positive integer that identifies the drawable.
The host time, in seconds, when the drawable was displayed onscreen.
A specialized view that creates, configures, and displays Metal objects.
Returns the class used to create the layer for instances of this class.
Render, compose, and animate visual elements.
A layer that supports drawing OpenGL content in iOS and tvOS applications.
Metadata describing how extended dynamic range (EDR) values should be tone mapped.
An object that manages image-based content and allows you to perform animations on that content.
Methods that model a hierarchical timing system, allowing objects to map time between their parent and local time.
A Metal drawable associated with a Core Animation layer.
A Core Animation layer that Metal can render into, typically displayed onscreen.
A Boolean value that determines whether requests for a new buffer expire if the system can’t satisfy them.
The color space of the rendered content.
The properties of the Metal performance heads-up display.
The Metal device responsible for the layer’s drawable resources.
A Boolean value that determines whether the layer synchronizes its updates to the display’s refresh rate.
The size, in pixels, of textures for rendering layer content.
Metadata describing the tone mapping to apply to the extended dynamic range (EDR) values in the layer.
A Boolean value that determines whether the layer’s textures are used only for rendering.
The number of Metal drawables in the resource pool managed by Core Animation.
Waits until a Metal drawable is available, and then returns it.
The pixel format of the layer’s textures.
The device object that the system recommends using for this layer.
A Boolean value that determines whether the layer presents its content using a Core Animation transaction.
Enables extended dynamic range values onscreen.
A layer that provides a layer suitable for rendering OpenGL content.
A layer that allows an application to render a layer tree into a Core OpenGL context.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
